thread.title: What’s the sweet spot for term deposits?
thread.title_full: What’s the sweet spot for term deposits?

author: ANTHONY KEANE
title: What’s the sweet spot for term deposits?
text:
SIX months is the sweet spot for term deposits right now - so with official interest rates at historical lows, make sure you shop around for the best rate for your savings.
New research by Canstar shows average term deposit rates for two and three month deposits are 2.21 per cent and 2.55 per cent respectively, while a 12 month deposit pays you 2.71 per cent.
However, locking in for six months can deliver you up to 3.5 per cent a year, at ME Bank, it says.
“That’s significantly higher than anything else available,” says Canstar research manager Mitchell Watson.
“In fact, investors would need to lock their money away for five years in order to replicate that return.”
Watson says anyone seeking a term deposit or approaching the end of their existing term should research available interest rates, and not be afraid to look outside their preferred term if a higher rate is out there.
He says online comparison websites and visiting your lender’s website are good places to start.
Don’t just automatically roll over your term deposit into the same time frame, because rates can change dramatically as banks juggle their offerings.
“We hear that term deposits tend to be quite sticky and people rollover onto the same rate, but the market can change for better or worse,” Watson says.
Reserve Bank of Australia figures show that average term deposit interest rates have more than halved in the past four years, from above 6 per cent to below 3 per cent.
Goldsborough Financial Services director Glenn Todman says they remain popular for conservative investors and many retirees. “If you want security you have no alternative — you are going to have to accept the low rate,” he says.
“People say buy bank shares instead and take the (higher) dividend, but let’s face it — Commonwealth Bank shares recently lost 10 per cent of their value. It’s all very well getting a 5 per cent dividend, but if you lose 10 per cent of your capital it defeats the purpose.”
Todman warns that shopping around and chopping and changing banks won’t always be worth the effort. “If you have got $10,000 and can get an extra 0.15 per cent, it’s $15 a year.
“Ask your bank at the time what is their best rate, and what is the term of that best rate, and see whether that suits you.”
